documentation:
The sockets package allows you to open TCP sockets to servers or to create a TCP server socket
  yourself.

  The following is a very basic example of opening a TCP socket to make an HTTP request and print
  the first 140 characters of the response.
  ```
  ğŸ“¦ sockets ğŸ”´

  ğŸ ğŸ‡
    ğŸ¦ socket ğŸš‡ ğŸ”·ğŸ“ğŸ†• ğŸ”¤www.emojicode.orgğŸ”¤ 80
    ğŸ’¬ socket ğŸ“‡ ğŸ”¤GET / HTTP/1.1âŒrâŒnHost: www.emojicode.orgâŒrâŒnâŒrâŒnğŸ”¤

    ğŸ¦ data ğŸº ğŸ‘‚ socket 140
    ğŸ˜€ ğŸº ğŸ”¡ data
  ğŸ‰
  ```

  At the time of writing this, the above code would return something similar to:
  ```
  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Server: GitHub.com
  Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
  Last-Modified: Thu, 13 Apr 2017 16:49:52 GMT
  Access-Control-Al
  ```

  Here weâ€™ve an example of a minimal echo-server that listens on port 8728. The server simply sends
  back a copy of the data it received.
  ```
  ğŸ“¦ sockets ğŸ”´

  ğŸ‘´ Simple echo server listening on port 8728
  ğŸ ğŸ‡
    ğŸ¦ server ğŸš‡ ğŸ”·ğŸ„ğŸ†• 8728

    ğŸ” ğŸ‘ ğŸ‡
      ğŸ¦ clientSocket ğŸº ğŸ™‹ server
      ğŸ” ğŸ‘ ğŸ‡
        ğŸ¦ readData ğŸ‘‚ clientSocket 50
        ğŸŠğŸ¦ data readData ğŸ‡
          ğŸ‘´ Weâ€™ve read 50 bytes and send them back
          ğŸ’¬ clientSocket data
        ğŸ‰
      ğŸ‰
    ğŸ‰
  ğŸ‰
  ```

  Of course, the code above is minimal and incomplete. For example, it can handle only one
  connection.

classes.name: ğŸ„
classes.documentation: ğŸ„ represents a socket that listens for clients on a given port.

methods.name: ğŸ™‹
methods.documentation:
Waits until a client wants to connect to this socket and returns a socket
    to communicate with it.

Creates a ğŸ„ instance that immediately starts listening on the given port.
    This initializer returns Nothingness if the socket canâ€™t be bound to the

classes.name: ğŸ“
classes.documentation: ğŸ“ represents a socket for communication between client and server.

methods.name: ğŸ’¬
methods.documentation:
Sends the given data to the peer. Returns true if the data was successfully
    sent or false on error.

methods.name: ğŸ‘‚
methods.documentation:
Tries to read up to *bytes* bytes from the socket. Nothingness is returned
    on error or if the socket was closed by the peer.

initializers.name: ğŸ†•
initializers.documentation:
Opens a socket to *address*. *address* can be a host name which will be
    resolved.
